awd_titl_txt: RUI: Dual Domain Organogels: A Novel Material Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Polymer gels are solid-like materials that are mostly composed of liquid.  They appear in a wide variety of applications ranging from food and cosmetic products, to agricultural uses, to pharmaceuticals and biomedical devices, and also are relevant to water sustainability.  Nearly all research on "loaded gels" thus far has concentrated on water-based materials since water is abundant, versatile, and biocompatible.  However, loaded gels comprised of hydrocarbon solvent (e.g., mineral oil), instead of water, offer many benefits including greatly improved shelf life and elimination of complicated water-polymer and water-nanocarrier interactions. This RUI (Research in Undergraduate Institutions) project will deliver an approach to fabricate hydrocarbon-based gels loaded with nanocarriers. Then, principles correlating gel formulation quantities with resultant nanoscale structure and subsequently nanoscale structure with release rate of the nanocarriers and gel physical characteristics (e.g., flexibility and strength) will be established. These results will provide a fundamental understanding of the isolated effects of loaded gel nanostructure on practical properties. Furthermore, the findings will contribute to future developments of loaded gel materials in the health, agricultural, water-sustainability, and related industries. Of equal importance to its technical contributions, this work will be partially conducted by undergraduate STEM students, thereby cultivating their scientific/technical expertise and interests.  The students will also be exposed to cutting-edge instrumentation and research at national laboratories.  The principal investigator, along with support from these aspiring engineers/scientists, will apply acquired knowledge in undergraduate teaching and middle/high school outreach activities.


Part 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Polymer gels extend the usefulness of macromolecules, including their ability to be loaded with nanocarrier species such as micelles, vesicles, and nanoparticles. Nanocarrier-loaded polymer gels exhibit superior properties over their stand-alone constituents (i.e., payload-containing gels and nanocarriers dispersed in liquids), which is particularly beneficial in applications where high payload storage and slow, steady release are desired, such as in agricultural and pharmaceutical delivery devices. This RUI award supports investigation of loaded block copolymer organogels (referred to as dual domain organogels (DDOGs) or their block copolymer and nanocarrier domains) wherein the solvent and block copolymer are nonpolar hydrocarbons and the nanocarriers are reverse micelles. This makeup eliminates the complex, long-range interactions, such as electrostatic and dipole-dipole forces, present in hydrogels as well as eradicates dependence on a single solvent and greatly extends shelf-life. Objectives of the work include: (i) synthesis of formulation-structure design rules for DDOGs such that a number of their nanoscale features can be methodically tailored, and (ii) establishment of structure-property relationships for reverse micelle diffusion and mechanical behavior in the tailored organogels.  The results from this work will not only advance the scientific communities' understanding of loaded gel formulation and properties, but may also inform use of these materials in a number of high-impact technologies including sensors, water purification, ion-exchange processes (e.g., batteries), agriculture, and health.  Of equal importance, the work will cultivate the careers of undergraduate STEM students including exceptional experiences to operate cutting-edge instrumentation at national laboratories, interpret resultant data, and present their findings. The principal investigator, along with support from these aspiring engineers/scientists, will extend acquired knowledge to inform undergraduate teaching and middle/high school outreach activities.
.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to generate a better understanding of loaded block copolymer organogels ? gels containing a model drug that are primarily composed of mineral oil and that can be thermally reprocessed. Materials similar to these have recently been considered for application as transdermal drug delivery media (for example, nicotine patches) and therefore understanding things like their drug delivery rate (transport properties) and stiffness (mechanical properties) is of high value. The current project specifically sought to relate the identities and amounts of various gel components (mineral oil, copolymer, and model drug) to the resultant microscopic structure of gels and subsequently make connections between that structure and gels? transport and mechanical properties. These correlations, when considered collectively, yield formulation-structure-property relationships for loaded block copolymer organogels that will be useful in the future design of these materials.

The main outcomes of this research include:

1. Development of a new measurement technique that quantifies solute diffusivity through organogels. Solute diffusivity is the fundamental parameter that describes how quickly a solute (i.e., a model drug) moves through a gel. The developed method uses a mineral oil submersion bath and infrared spectroscopy to monitor solute concentration over time, which is then converted into a diffusivity value using a mathematical model.

2. Establishment of detailed relationships between copolymer parameters and microscopic structure including the size of spherical domains that are inherent to these types of gels (and are necessary for them to behave like solids rather than liquids), the spacing between these domains, and the degree of interconnection between the domains. Generally, longer copolymer molecules yield larger spherical domains and larger inter-domain spacing whereas high copolymer concentration translates to larger spherical domains, smaller inter-domain spacing, and increased domain interconnectivity. Mathematical expressions that describe each of these relationships were generated and can be used to design gels of desired structure (and consequently properties). Our research also found that presence of various model drugs did not have a significant effect on gels? microscopic structure.

3. Establishment of relationships between gels spherical domain size, domain concentration, domain interconnectivity, and total copolymer concentration and gels. mechanical stiffness and release rate of model drug. In the case of both properties, results show that total copolymer concentration, which reflects how many individual copolymer chains are present in a gel, has the biggest effect on properties: increased concentration leads to stiffer gels and slower model drug release. Spherical domain size and concentration were shown to have a weak effect on both properties (same trends as for copolymer concentration). Domain interconnectivity plays a moderate role in gel stiffness (more translates to higher) but does not affect model drug release rate. Somewhat surprisingly, inter-domain spacing did not affect model drug release rate.

4. Identification of strategies to decouple the transport and mechanical properties of loaded block copolymer organogels. The first strategy applies one advantage of organogels ? they aren?t linked to one specific liquid component. We found that, by swapping the gel?s liquid (mineral oil) for one with a different viscosity, the diffusion of model drug can be easily tailored while the mechanical behavior remains unchanged. Alternatively, we established design rules that enable the interconnectedness of gels? spherical domains to be tuned simply using mixtures of two different block copolymers, which causes changes in mechanical properties but maintains a constant model drug diffusion rate.

5. Support and train for 13 undergraduate and 3 Masters students. Our work resulted in 6 publications in technical journals and 20 presentations at (inter)national conferences to date. Prominently, 6 undergraduate student co-authors appear on these publications, and 9 presentations were made by undergraduate students.

6. Development of two unique outreach activities designed to expose middle and high school students to materials and polymer science. Activities were delivered to students at Bucknell University?s Engineering Summer Camp for three consecutive summers.


Last Modified: 08/15/2023
Modified by: Kenny Mineart
